2.15.1.title: Overview
2.15.1.content:
Managed Pressure Drilling (MPD) uses surface back pressure to precisely control wellbore pressure.

**Key Concept:**
BHP = Hydrostatic Head + Annular Friction Loss (ECD) + Surface Back Pressure (SBP)

**Why Used:**
- Narrow drilling window (pore pressure close to fracture pressure)
- Reduces kick/loss events
- Better wellbore stability
- Improved ROP in some cases
- Enables drilling undrillable wells

**Well Control Implications:**
- SBP provides additional control
- RCD is NOT a barrier
- Must be able to transition to conventional well control
- Different response procedures needed

2.15.2.title: MPD Barrier Philosophy
2.15.2.content:
**Primary Barrier:**
Hydrostatic head + Annular friction + Surface back pressure

**Secondary Barrier:**
BOP system (unchanged from conventional)

**Critical Understanding:**
- RCD (Rotating Control Device) is a pressure CONTAINMENT device
- RCD is NOT a barrier element
- If RCD fails, must have immediate response
- Two-barrier principle still applies

**MPD System Status:**
- MPD system must be monitored continuously
- Failure modes understood
- Backup plans in place
- Cannot rely on MPD as a barrier

2.15.3.title: Kick Detection in MPD
2.15.3.content:
**Advantages:**
- Constant BHP monitoring (when equipped)
- Can detect smaller influxes
- More precise pressure control
- Mass balance monitoring available

**Detection Methods:**
- Return flow rate vs pump rate
- Coriolis meter for mass balance
- Downhole pressure monitoring
- Pit volume (as conventional)

**Challenges:**
- More complex system to monitor
- SBP variations may mask small kicks
- RCD seal leakage can cause false indications

**Response to Indicators:**
- Increase SBP to stop influx
- If successful: adjust mud weight to eliminate need for SBP
- If unsuccessful: transition to conventional well control

2.15.4.title: MPD Kick Response
2.15.4.content:
**Minor Influx (MPD Controllable):**
1. Detect influx through monitoring
2. Increase SBP to stop influx
3. Circulate out influx at constant BHP
4. Adjust mud weight to eliminate SBP need
5. Resume normal MPD operations

**Major Influx (Requires Conventional WC):**
1. Increase SBP to maximum available
2. If influx continues: shut in on BOP
3. Transition to conventional well control
4. Use standard kill procedures

**Transition to Conventional:**
1. Close BOP
2. Record SIDPP and SICP
3. Transfer control from MPD choke to conventional choke
4. Kill using standard methods
5. Do not revert to MPD until situation controlled

2.15.5.title: RCD Failure Response
2.15.5.content:
**Signs of RCD Failure:**
- Loss of annular seal
- Unable to maintain SBP
- Flow from RCD
- Pressure anomalies

**Immediate Response:**
1. Attempt to re-establish seal (if designed for it)
2. If cannot seal: stop rotation
3. Close BOP annular
4. Transfer to conventional mode
5. Assess RCD and repair/replace

**Maintaining Well Control:**
- BOP provides backup
- May need to increase mud weight
- Cannot rely on SBP without RCD seal
- Have contingency procedure in place

2.15.6.title: MPD System Failure
2.15.6.content:
**Failure Types:**
- Choke failure
- Pump failure (if used for MPD)
- Control system failure
- Power failure

**Response:**
1. Close BOP to maintain pressure
2. Switch to conventional well control mode
3. Repair/restore MPD system
4. Only resume MPD when system fully functional

**Key Principle:**
MPD system failure should not cause loss of well control. BOP is always available as conventional backup.

2.15.7.title: Personnel and Training
2.15.7.content:
**Additional Requirements:**
- MPD-specific training
- Understanding of MPD system operation
- Ability to transition to conventional
- Knowledge of RCD limitations

**Crew Roles:**
- Dedicated MPD operator typically present
- Driller still responsible for well control
- Clear handoff procedures for emergencies

**Drills:**
- Include MPD-specific scenarios
- Practice transition to conventional
- RCD failure response
- System failure response

**Documentation:**
- MPD parameters recorded
- All pressure data logged
- Influx events documented
- System performance tracked
